column1: 1 - What is path of knowledge? What is its goal?
column2: It is one of the spiritual paths where goal is destruction of ignorance.
column3: We get all wishes fulfilled here, that is the only goal
column4: It is a lifestyle, where knowledge is gained for success.
column5: It is a way which leads to liberation of the person.
column6: It is a useless activity, only superstition nothing else
column7: A path to obtain knowledge of the entire existence. It's goal is knowledge in and of itself.
column8: The Path of Knowledge is a spiritual path in which knowledge is gained via direct experience and logic. We focus on gaining knowledge of the Existence, who we are,  and our relationship to the Existence. The goal of the Path of Knowledge is destruction of ignorance which ultimately leads to Self-Realization.

column1: 2 - What is knowledge?
column2: When interrelations are formed between experiences that are logical and consistent,  results in knowledge . Knowledge and information are different in that knowledge is obtained via direct experience and logic, while information can be obtained through sources other than our direct experience and logic, such as books or Gurus.
column3: Information that can be trusted is knowledge
column4: Knowledge is information gained by reading textbooks, scriptures.
column5: knowledge is information gained directly from authentic sources like scientists, experts etc.
column6: Whatever Guru says is knowledge.
column7: Whatever the education system teaches is knowledge
column8: Interrelations of Experience organized in memory is the definition of knowledge in the Path of Knowledge program. Knowledge and information are different in that knowledge is obtained via direct experience and logic, while information can be obtained through sources other than our direct experience and logic, such as books or Gurus.

column1: 3 - Which qualities can be cultivated, which ones cannot be cultivated?
column2: critical thinking, intelligence, and attention can be cultivated. Curiosity can not be cultivated.
column3: curiosity can be developed, intelligence can not
column4: critical thinking and a desire for knowledge can be cultivated, intelligence can not
column5: knowledge can be cultivated, wisdom can not
column6: attention can be cultivated, awareness can not
column7: no qualities can be cultivated, a seeker arrives with a fixed set of qualities
column8: Genuine curiosity and interest in spiritual matters is required to even begin on a spiritual path. Further, intense desire for knowledge and liberation is required. Subgoals of the path can include other important qualities of a seeker which include attention, one's intellect, open minded skepticism, and other critical thinking abilities.

column1: 4 - Why is all that changes false?
column2: All that changes is false because the criterion for truth is that which is unchanging
column3: All that changes is not false
column4: Change implies impermanence. it will not remain, that's why it's false.
column5: That which changes is an illusion, therefore it is not what it seems
column6: All that changes is unreliable and ultimately false
column7: There is no true or false
column8: True is subjective and arbitrary and dependent upon the criterion used for truth. In the PoK we define truth as that which is unchanging. Therefore, anything that does not meet that criterion is considered false.

column1: 5 - If knowledge comes from experience, which is false, how can we say that it is knowledge?
column2: Knowledge is subtractive and nothing is ultimately gained.
column3: Knowledge of the false Illusion is necessary for self-realization.
column4: Even though Experience is false, the brain stores Experience in Local Memory and we refer to that as knowledge.
column5: The Experiencer gains knowledge of itself through false, illusory forms which leads to self-realization.
column6: Books and Guru's impart knowledge through their Experience and if it fits with our direct experience, we then can call it knowledge.
column7: Not all experience is false. The one and only true experience is self-realization, and that is knowledge.
column8: We utilize the Experience, which is illusory and false, to reduce ignorance and blind beliefs via knowledge. Therefore, knowledge is a tool derived from the illusion to lead us to that which is true through subtracting all that is false.

column1: 6 - Why is the experiencer limited by experience?
column2: The Experiencer can never be limited by Experience.
column3: Since the Experiencer and Experience are one, they are both limited by the senses.
column4: For survival purposes.
column5: The Existence can only appear to itself through a limited Experiencer
column6: The Experiencer desires form. Thus the formless takes the form of the Experience
column7: Nothing can be known unless the Experiencer is limited by Experience
column8: The Experiencer is infinite and not limited by Experience. If the Experiencer were limited, we would need to identify and count the limited Experiencers. Who is identifying and counting those limited Experiencers? This shows that the Experiencer is unlimited, infinite, and can never be seen as limited.

column1: 7 - What is the definition of nature? What happens when it changes?
column2: Nature is the most fundamental essence of something. If it changes, it is not the nature.
column3: Nature is the natural occurence of vibration. When it changes, structures in the memory form.
column4: Nature is the most fundamental essence of something. If it changes, the nature can never be known.
column5: Nature is the phenomenon of the physical world. When it changes, life emerges.
column6: Nature is the phenomenon of the physical world. When it changes, the systems entropy increases
column7: Nature is truth. Truth can never change.
column8: Nature is the most fundamental essence of something. In the PoK we attempt to determine the Nature of Existence. We utilize the criterion for truth, which is "that which is unchanging" to determine the Nature of the Existence. We see that the only unchanging aspect of this Existence is the witnessing of Experience, or the Experiencer itself. When we look closer to see what the Nature of the Experiencer is, we see nothing. Only Emptiness. We can reach the conclusion that Emptiness is the Nature of the Existence.

column1: 8 - Experiencer knows itself via many forms, but why does it need so many forms when it can know itself with one form?
column2: The Experiencer is formless and has no need for form.
column3: To gain knowledge best suitable for it's survival as an individual.
column4: Because form is impermanent, it must identify with infinite forms to know itself
column5: It must obtain many different view points to view the entirety of it's creation
column6: This question falls under the category of unknowable and is thus unanswerable
column7: It only requires one form, which is the causal body in order to know itself.
column8: The Experiencer is infinite and formless. It knows itself by being itself.  It is the whole of the Existence. It does not require multiple forms to know itself.

column1: 9 - Establish the illusory nature of all forms.
column2: The essence of form is emptiness and forms do not exist independently. The water appears as a wave but is not separate from it.
column3: All forms are not illusory
column4: Since all is illusion so all forms are illusory
column5: That which changes is untrue, therefore it is an illusion.
column6: All forms are creations of the Experiencer and as creations they are illusory.
column7: It is impossible to establish the illusory nature of all forms
column8: The Experience is the part of the Existence that appears to the Experiencer. However, at the level of nonduality, there is nothing to the Experience other than the Experiencing of it. It shares the essence of the Experiencer which is emptiness. Experiences or forms do not exist independently. They are the waves that appear on the water but are not separate from the water.

column1: 10 - How can we say there is only one experiencer?
column2: If they are many then they must be witnessed. As soon as they are witnessed, they become experience and the one who witnesses them becomes the Experiencer. With this logic, it's impossible to have more than one Experiencer.
column3: We can't say there is only one Experiencer as each person has their own Experiencer.
column4: Because we have not seen it and because other people say, it really must be only one.
column5: We can not say there is only one experiencer.
column6: There is not even one Experiencer, there are no Experiencers.
column7: Each person shares the same Experiencer which is transmitted through our senses.
column8: The Experiencer is that which witnesses all Experience. If we attempt to count the number of Experiencers, who is the one counting? If we see an Experiencer, that Experiencer becomes an Experience and thus can not be an Experiencer. The Experiencer "stand behind" all Experiences. We take each person as an "Experiencer" because we falsely believe that the Experiencer is this body and mind. The body and mind appear to the Experiencer.

column1: 1. What happens when the seeker does not have required qualities and still tries to practice?
column2: Without intense desire for liberation, which is the most essential quality for taking on a spiritual path; the practices will not be in the right direction and the seeker will be lost for a long time. Seekr can also harm self.
column3: Makes some progress on the spiritual path.
column4: It is a total waste of time and effort.
column5: Seeker develops the qualities because of whatever practice s/he does.
column6: Achieves material success.
column7: Seeker reaches the spiritual goal still.
column8: Intense desire for knowledge, liberation, and also curiosity are required for a spiritual seeker. If these are not present, it's unlikely that a seeker will even find the Path of Knowledge to begin with. If they do begin the path, interest will be lost quickly without these skills. Further, if they do not develop the secondary qualities of critical thinking or attention, progress will be halted and they will likely revert back to old habits such as believing blind beliefs and will not use their direct experience and logic to acquire knowledge.

column1: 2. When we get knowledge, what do we get essentially?
column2: We don't get anything, all ignorance is dropped leaving that which is always there, the essence.
column3: We realize how to be successful in the world.
column4: We get knowledge of various spiritual paths.
column5: We get knowledge about ourself and the world.
column6: We get increased Awareness
column7: We get bliss and happiness
column8: In the Path of Knowledge, knowledge is defined as an organization of Experiences within the Memory. The knowledge we seek on the PoK is subtractive, that is, it removes our blind beliefs and ignorance, bringing us to our essence. Bliss, happiness, freedom, arise naturally from this.

column1: 3. Why is a guru not a valid means of knowledge? Why do we still need a guru?
column2: There are only two valid means of knowledge: Direct experience and logic. Guru is not a valid means of knowledge because he will provide information which still needs to be validated by seeker through his own experience. Also Guru can be fake too. However, we still need a Guru because it is Guru who will point out the right direction.
column3: Guru is a valid means of knowledge.
column4: Guru is not a valid means of knowledge because we do not know whether he is trustworthy or not. We still need him to share practices with us.
column5: Knowledge is received through scriptures. We still need a Guru to interpret the scriptures for us.
column6: Guru is not a valid means because he is a person. We still need him because the tradition demands a Guru.
column7: Guru is not a valid means of knowledge and we do not need a Guru.
column8: Everything other than direct experience and logic should be considered information, including the Guru. Information can point us to the knowledge but it is up to us to see for ourselves. It is important to critically appraise all information including that which comes from a Guru.

column1: 4. Who is transformed by Self realisation?
column2: Nobody is transformed. Transformation happens and there is freedom from the person.
column3: The person.
column4: Mind and body.
column5: Nobody is transformed.
column6: Self realisation is a myth.
column7: Soul
column8: Self-realization is the recognition that we are not any thing that can be pointed to within our Experience, including the mind or body. We realize that we are pure subjectivity, or the Experiencer itself. Second, we see that the Experiencer can not be separate from the Experience. There can not be two. We see that we are the whole Existence. Ultimately, no person or individual is transformed. There was no person or individual to begin with, only oneness.

column1: 5. What is nondual truth?
column2: In non-duality there is oneness that embraces both truth and false.
column3: There is no false.
column4: Everything is false.
column5: Truth is supreme.
column6: There is only one existence.
column7: Experiencer and experience are the same.
column8: Non-dual truth can not be expressed in words. We are the whole of the Existence, One. Silence is the only expression for this. The moment we attempt to describe Non-dual truth, we objectify it and duality arises.

column1: 6. What is memory?
column2: Memory is a special pattern of vibrations which can take on form of other patterns( vibrations ). It "Stores" the incoming change and can be "Played back" later.
column3: Memory is humans ability to recall something
column4: Memory is storage space in human brain
column5: Experiences are memory
column6: Memory is not a thing, it is the Experiencer appearing as a form so that it can Experience itself in many forms.
column7: Memory is a function of the brain which stores the incoming vibrations as a formatted sensory input
column8: In the realm of Experience, the fundamental building block is vibration, a simple binary state change. There is also a tendency towards survival or reduction of disorder. These vibrations superimpose and self-perpetuate. Eventually, vibrational patterns arise that can take on incoming vibrations and can "replay" the incoming patterns. This is called Memory. Memory can then build more complex structures that filter incoming data for the benefit of the structure, these are called the senses. Remember that this explanation is firmly in the realm of "illusion" or the Experience and can not be said to be True based on our criteria for truth. It is a model to explain the Experience.

column1: 7. What is the difference between waking, dreaming and projected states?
column2: Essentially they are the same but the experiences in each can be different. Operating senses in each state are different.
column3: Waking is real but dreaming is unreal. Projected is also unreal.
column4: Realisation is possible in waking and not in dreaming or projected.
column5: Dreaming is in lower layer and waking in higher layer
column6: The brain waves are vibrating at various patterns which produce a specific state.
column7: The Experiencer is different in each state depending on the particular senses that are aquired in that state.
column8: Once we have the knowledge that we are the Experiencer of all Experiences and that we are actually the whole Existence itself, we see that there is fundamental difference between waking, dreaming, or projected. Experiences arise there which will change. The Experiences will be witnessed by You, the Experiencer. We take the waking state to be "real" and the other states to be false simply due to the appearance of stability and our familiarity with our stable, 5 senses. Change is slower in the waking state compared to the other states. Other states may also have different senses compared to the waking state senses.

column1: 8. Which layers are needed for awareness?
column2: Higher layers that go beyond intellect, as well as all of the lower layersz.
column3: Layers are not needed.
column4: Refined emotional layers can give one the experience of awareness
column5: Experience of oneness
column6: Layer where one experiences love
column7: Layer of intellect
column8: In order for Awareness to arise, which is the knowledge that "I Am the Experiencer", "this Experience is illusory", or "I Am this Existence" we must go beyond intellect and at the same time we must also have all of the lower layers in working order. For example, if the most basic survival needs are not met, this entity will be searching for food or shelter, rather than inquiring about the nature of it's existence. Intellect and critical thinking allows us to investigate until the light of Awareness is known directly but again, will not arise until all lower layers are adequately tended to.

column1: 9. How to go beyond the illusion?
column2: You are already beyond the illusion right now. One only has to realise there is illusion, and it will always be there.
column3: Through meditation.
column4: Through grace of Guru.
column5: By understanding the illusion.
column6: By gaining knowledge.
column7: By dropping ignorance.
column8: No action will take one beyond the illusion, it is a recognition which is here and now that shows you are already beyond the illusion. You are the Experiencer of the illusion and ultimately the Existence itself

column1: 10. How can the limited know the unlimited?
column2: Limited cannot know the unlimited. It has to accept that unlimited cannot be known.
column3: By becoming the unlimited.
column4: Through realisation.
column5: By dropping the mind.
column6: Through special senses.
column7: Through refined intelligence.
column8: Knowing implies that something was experienced and logically organized in the memory. In order for something to be known, it must be formatted by the senses in such a way that it is useful and logical. Thus, we perceive Experience to be limited because it relies on the limits of the senses. By definition, the limited can never "know" the unlimited because the unlimited can not be limited. If we could ever know the unlimited it will become limited. Therefore, we can only be the unlimited we can never know the unlimited.

column1: 1. What is the goal of the path of knowledge and what is gained here?
column2: reduction of ignorance, nothing is gained
column3: happiness and freedom, improvement in worldly interactions and relationships
column4: freedom from suffering, knowledge of the existence
column5: happiness and freedom, increased awareness
column6: maintaining awareness at all times, attention and focus
column7: destruction of the ego, knowledge of the existence
column8: Although freedom, happiness, improvement in worldly interactions and relations, as well as increased attention and awareness can occur as side effects on the path of knowledge, these are not the goal. The goal is reduction of ignorance through the acquisition of knowledge. This is a subtractive path and nothing is gained.

column1: 2. What is the universal truth which is accepted by everyone?
column2: There is no universal truth accepted by everyone
column3: Life is suffering
column4: Our essence is unknowable
column5: The origin of the universe is unknowable
column6: Science is the key to explaining the universe
column7: Ignorance is the cause of suffering
column8: Truth is subjective and arbitrary. Everyone has a different criteria for truth. Truth is dependent upon the criteria which defines it. Therefore, there can not be a universal truth accepted by all. In the Path of Knowledge we define truth as that which is unchanging. All else is false, or illusion.

column1: 3. What is the nature of the Existence?
column2: Emptiness
column3: Energy
column4: Space
column5: Sub atomic particles
column6: doesn't have nature
column7: God
column8: The Existence appears to have two aspects: that which is changing and that which is unchanging. The Experience which is ever changing and the Experiencer, which is unchanging. Essence is defined as the most fundamental, perfect, and unchanging component of a system. Therefore, the essence of the Existence is that which is unchanging, or the Experiencer. Going one step further, when we search to find exactly what this Experiencer is, we find nothing. When we look at the Experience we can not find any object which stands independently of the Experiencer. Therefore, we say that the essence of the Existence is emptiness.

column1: 4. If it is not an object, how is the Experiencer known?
column2: By being the Experiencer
column3: Through logic and inference. If there is an experience, there must be an experiencer
column4: Through progressive elimination of what is not me (Neti-Neti)
column5: Through awareness practice
column6: Through attention practice
column7: Through direct experience in the waking, dreaming, and projected states
column8: Although the Experiencer can be inferred, given that there is the appearance of objects and objects can not appear without an Experiencer, the only way to "know" the Experiencer is by being the Experiencer. Many practices, such as progressive elimination (neti-neti) and meditative practices can help one become the Experiencer but they are not required. Only reduction of ignorance is required to see that you are the Experiencer.

column1: 5. When the Experiencer is without any qualities, why do we say it is blissful?
column2: Bliss is the absence of all qualities, thus the Experiencer is bliss
column3: Realizing the Experiencer causes joy and happiness for the person
column4: It allows for a sense of oneness with all things
column5: Through the Experiencer, we experience Nirvana
column6: The Experiencer loves and accepts everything
column7: Because the Experiencer is perfect in all ways
column8: Bliss is emptiness and emptiness is bliss. Bliss is the absence of happiness, sadness and all states of the mind. The Experiencer itself is Emptiness. Therefore the Experiencer is bliss.

column1: 6. If it is all Emptiness, how can things exist at all?
column2: Through the potential of emptiness
column3: Through atomic and molecular organization
column4: There is nothing, there is no existence of anything
column5: Through the senses and the mind
column6: It is a creation of the Experiencer
column7: Through the "big bang"
column8: In the Path of Knowledge, emptiness does not mean that nothing exists at all, it means that nothing exists independently and that there is no essential substance which creates objects. At the most fundamental level, all we can say is that this emptiness has a potential to appear as illusory forms.

column1: 7. What is the evidence for Vibration?
column2: The observation of change
column3: There is no evidence, it's only a concept
column4: Scientific experiments
column5: In meditative states, the vibrations can be observed in the mind
column6: Through direct observation via the five senses
column7: Mathematical derivation
column8: Change is the evidence for vibration.  We know by direct experience that all Experience is changing. The most basic change would be the root of all phenomenon. A change must have at least two states. Not less and not more. By necessity, the simplest change must have two states, which is called a binary change. We call this binary change a vibration. This is the basic building block of all Experience.

column1: 8. The layered structure of memory is evolving, what happens to it in the end?
column2: Dissolution
column3: The Atman merges with the Brahman
column4: Knowledge of the entire Existence
column5: A higher intellect is achieved
column6: Nirvana
column7: Awakening or self-realization
column8: Evolution of the layered structure of memory eventually leads to the dissolved layer, or the universal memory, which is not really a layer, but a container for all layers. Although awakening and liberation are part of the evolution of the layered memory, they are not the highest layer of the memory structure.

column6: Helping others in need, maintain awareness at all times

column8: After realizing your nondual nature, you are free to do what you would like within the illusion. There is nothing more to know and nothing more important than self-realization. We know that ignorance resulting from indoctrination and blind beliefs are what lead to suffering. A minimilist lifestyle without becoming enmeshed in the burdens of daily life will promote knowledge and the dropping of ignorance.

column1: 10. What is unconditional love, how is it related to my true nature?
column2: Oneness is unconditional love, and the Experiencer is not separate from the Experience and is Existence itself.
column3: Unconditional love is loving no matter what, which is what the Experiencer does
column4: Unconditional love is not possible, all love is conditional
column5: Unconditional love is freedom and can be felt via self-realization
column6: Unconditional love is oneness with all things, the Experiencer allows the person to love all things

column8: Unconditional love is non-separation, oneness. When we realize our true nature, we know we are the Experiencer and thus we are the whole of the Existence. This is oneness. Therefore, we are not separate from anyone or anything in this existence. We are unconditional love.

column1: 1. What is the difference between knowledge and truth?
column2: Knowledge is organization and interrelation of experiences, truth is a categorization of experience.
column3: There is no difference.
column4: Knowledge is obtained via direct experience, truth is obtained via logic.
column5: There is no difference, both remove ignorance.
column6: Knowledge is subjective and arbitrary and truth is unchanging.
column7: Knowledge is unchanging, truth removes ignorance.
column8: In the PoK we define knowledge as an organization or interrelation of experience within the memory. Truth is arbitrary and subjective. It depends on the definition. In the PoK we define Truth as that which is not changing. Truth is thus a categorization of Experience. We categorize Experience as either changing (false) or unchanging (true).

column1: 2. Can we get knowledge from scriptures or books?
column2: No, knowledge is only obtained via direct experience and logic.
column3: Yes, if you are in agreement with the author.
column4: Yes, but only if they are from valid sources of knowledge, such as a Guru.
column5: Yes, if the knowledge fits with our direct experience.
column6: No, only the words directly from a Guru will allow for knowledge.
column7: Yes, if the book removes ignorance.
column8: Scriptures, books, Gurus, podcasts, and anything other than our direct experience and logic is considered information. Direct experience and logic are our only valid means of knowledge on the PoK. All else is considered information. Information can point us to knowledge but it is not the knowledge itself.

column1: 3. What is the difference between your true nature and nature of a rock?
column2: There is no difference.
column3: My true nature is emptiness, the rock's is unknown.
column4: Both are potential.
column5: My true nature is the Experiencer, the rock's is the Experience.
column6: Vibrations are the true nature of both.
column7: Potential is my true nature, the rock's is unknown.
column8: Essence is defined as the most fundamental, unchanging building block. Anything that is changing can not be our Essence. We see that the only unchanging aspect of this Existence is the Experiencer. What is the Essence of the Experiencer? Nothing that can be pointed to directly, it has no characteristics. We also see that the Experiencer is the Existence itself. There is no difference between the Experiences or the Experiencer within this Existence. If the Essence of the Experiencer is Emptiness we must say that the Essence of the Existence is Emptiness. Thus, anything that arises within this Existence can be said to have the same Essence, or True Nature, and that is Emptiness.

column1: 4. Are you a body?
column2: No, the body is an Experience.
column3: No, but the Experiencer takes the form of a body.
column4: No, but the body creates the Experiencer
column5: I am the causal body, not the physical body
column6: I am the physical body in this state but an astral body in the projected state
column7: It can not be known if I am the body
column8: In the PoK we define the Self, our True Nature, or Essence as that which is unchanging. We can see that the body is changing and impermanent, thus can not be our True Nature, Self, or Essence. We are the unchanging Experiencer of all changing Experiences. Thus, we are not the body. The body is an Experience. The same holds for the mind or ego.

column1: 5. Where is the experiencer in this body?
column2: There is no location of the Experiencer.
column3: At the crown chakra
column4: At the third eye chakra
column5: At the heart center
column6: It pervades the entire body
column7: Within the pre-frontal cortex
column8: Due to blind belief and lack of investigation, we falsely believe that the Experiencer arises within the body, usually somewhere in the head region. There is a sense of locality in this region which is beneficial for the survival of the organism. Although, when we look closely, we see that the Experiencer is non-local. If we can point to an object (such as our body) and say "that is the Experiencer", the Experiencer becomes the Experience. Where is the Experiencer? Always, "behind" the Experience. Thus, the Experiencer is not located in the body. It is non-local.

column1: 6. If I am the whole existence, and all experience is also existence why can't I know all the experiences?
column2: The senses limit Experience
column3: Lack of meditative skills and Siddhis
column4: The brain does not allow for an experience of the whole
column5: You can know all Experiences at once
column6: The Experiencer can only view one Experience at a time
column7: Lack of Awareness
column8: In this question, the word "know" implies a knower and a known. In order for their to be a known, the whole or unlimited must be limited so that the knower has a tangible, orderly Experience which is impressed upon the memory. The senses are developed for the purpose of survival. They limit sensory input to that which is beneficial to the organism. Thus, the whole, or unlimited must, by definition, be limited to be known. This is why "we" with our limited senses and local memory can never have a tangible Experience of the whole Existence.

column1: 7. What is the meaning of illusion?
column2: Something that is not what it appears to be
column3: A simulated reality
column4: that which is a modified representation of the truth
column5: the true aspect of the Existence
column6: that which changes
column7: that which is deceptive
column8: Illusion is an appearance which is not what it actually is. In the PoK this is also known as Maya. Illusion is the closest word in English to Maya. Maya implies that there is actually nothing to the illusions that arise, there isn't anything "behind" the appearance which is real, only Emptiness. All Experience can be seen as illusory from the perspective of the Experiencer.

column1: 8. What is awareness?
column2: Knowledge that I Am the Experiencer
column3: Focus on a particular object
column4: hypervigilance in all activities
column5: the ability to note the arisings and passings of Experience
column6: mindfulness
column7: breath based meditation
column8: Awareness is recollection that there is an Experiencer and that this Experience is illusory. It is not a meditative technique. Awareness is cutlivated by abiding as the Witness of all Experience. With time, eventually abiding will occur 24/7.

column1: 9. How can we know the nondual nature of the existence?
column2: It can not be known, we can only be the Existence.
column3: Through the Guru's teachings
column4: Through silencing of the mind
column5: Through progressive elimination or "Neti Neti"
column6: By attention and awareness practice
column7: By witnessing the merging of the Experiencer and Experience
column8: Knowing implies a "known" and a "knower". Knowing is a term that applies to duality. Thus, we can never know the nondual nature. We gain knowledge of the Self and recognize we are the Experiencer of all Experience. The next step is to see that the Experience is not separate from the Experiencer and thus we are the whole Existence. We can only be the Existence, the whole, or the Experience, we can never know it intellectually.

column1: 10. How to be blissful always?
column2: You are already blissful, always.
column3: Through the Guru's grace
column4: Through silencing of the mind
column5: Through progressive elimination or "Neti Neti"

column8: Emptiness is the absence of a tangible, independently existing substance, essence, or building block. We come to the realization that we are the Experiencer and the Experiencer is the whole Existence. When we look to see what the Experiencer actually is, we find nothing. There are no objective features, only pure subjectivity. Experience is an appearance with dependent existence. Experience is a propagation of multiple illusions (an object, sensed by the senses, and impressed on the memory). If an Experience is dependent on illusions which are themselves empty, then it too must be empty. Therefore, the nature of this Experience is Emptiness. Therefore, if both the Experiencer and the Experience are empty, then the whole Existence is Empty.  There are possibilities in Emptiness. There is potential in Emptiness to appear as Experience. Ignorance is the inability to see the series of illusions that create Experience.This potential in Emptiness seems to persist and repeat which creates perception of stability. The persistence in memory creates the illusion in time.

All Experience is that of the senses and since the senses are in continuity with the memory, we can say that all Experience is that of memory. Using direct experience and logic we remove the ignorance that creates the appearances of suffering. In other paths, there are preparatory practices, rites, and rituals, to gradually bring students to this Self-Realization. The PoK flips this and the goal is provided first. It is also known as the pathless path.

The goal is Self-Realization and destruction of ignorance.

When we add the essence of each, which is Emptiness, Emptiness is the only result. There is no substance that is the fundamental building block of this Existence.
